topic.title: Troubleshooting the installation

body.p: Review the following troubleshooting tips if you have problems with Zowe installation.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Troubleshooting installing Zowe runtime

body.p: The following topics contain information that can help you troubleshoot problems when you encounter unexpected behavior installing Zowe runtime.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Troubleshooting installing explorer server

body.p: If explorer server REST APIs do not function properly, check the following items:

li.p: Check whether your Liberty explorer server is running.

You can check this in the Display Active \(DA\) panel of SDSF under ISPF. The ZOWESVR started task should be running. If the ZOWESVR task is not running, start the explorer server by using the following START operator command:

You can also use the operator command /D A,ZOWESVR to verify whether the task is active, which alleviates the need for the DA panel of SDSF. If the started task is not running, ensure that your ZOWESVR procedure resides in a valid PROCLIB data set, and check the tasks job output for errors.
Check whether the explorer server is started without errors.
In the DA panel of SDSF under ISPF, select the ZOWESVR job to view the started task output. If the explorer server is started without errors, you can see the following messages:
li.codeblock: CWWKE0001I: The server Atlas has been launched.
CWWKF0011I: The server Atlas is ready to run a smarter planet.
li.p: If you see error messages that are prefixed with "ERROR" or stack traces in the ZOWESVR job output, respond to them.
Check whether the URL that you use to call explorer server REST APIs is correct. For example: https://your.server:atlasport/api/v1/system/version. The URL is case-sensitive.
Ensure that you enter a valid z/OS user ID and password when initially connecting to the explorer server.
If testing the explorer server REST API for jobs information fails, check the z/OSMF IZUSVR1 task output for errors. If no errors occur, you can see the following messages in the IZUSVR1 job output:
li.codeblock: CWWKE0001I : The server zosmfServer has been launched.
CWWKF0011I: The server zosmfServer is ready to run a smarter planet.
li.p: If you see error messages, respond to them.
For RESTJOBS, you can see the following message if no errors occur:
li.codeblock: CWWKZ0001I: Application IzuManagementFacilityRestJobs started in n.nnn seconds.
li.p: You can also call z/OSMF RESTJOBS APIs directly from your Internet browser with a URL, for example,
where the securezosmfport is 443 by default. You can verify the port number by checking the izu.https.port variable assignment in the z/OSMF bootstrap.properties file.

You might get error message IZUG846W, which indicates that a cross-site request forgery (CSRF) was attempted. To resolve the issue, update your browser by adding the X-CSRF-ZOSMF-HEADER HTTP custom header to every cross-site request. This header can be set to any value or an empty string (""). For details, see the z/OSMF documentation. If calling the z/OSMF RESTJOBS API directly fails, fix z/OSMF before explorer server can use these APIs successfully.

If testing the explorer server REST API for data set information fails, check the z/OSMF IZUSVR1 task output for errors and confirm that the z/OSMF RESTFILES services are started successfully. If no errors occur, you can see the following message in the IZUSVR1 job output:
li.codeblock: CWWKZ0001I: Application IzuManagementFacilityRestFiles started in n.nnn seconds.
li.p: To test z/OSMF REST APIs you can run curl scripts from your workstation.
where the securezosmfport is 443 by default. You can verify the port number by checking the izu.https.port variable assignment in the z/OSMF bootstrap.properties file.
/zosmf/restjobs/jobs?prefix=*&owner=* will return a list of the jobs.
If z/OSMF returns jobs correctly you can test whether it is able to returns files using

If the restfiles curl statement returns a TSO SERVLET EXCEPTION error check that the the z/OSMF installation step of creating a valid IZUFPROC procedure in your system PROCLIB has been completed. For more information, see the z/OSMF Configuration Guide.
The IZUFPROC member resides in your system PROCLIB, which is similar to the following sample:
Note: You might need to change paths and data sets names to match your installation.
A known issue and workaround for RESTFILES API can be found at TSO SERVLET EXCEPTION ATTEMPTING TO USE RESTFILE INTERFACE.
Check your system console log for related error messages and respond to them.

body.p: If the explorer server cannot connect to the z/OSMF server, check the following item:

By default, the explorer server communicates with the z/OSMF server on the localhost address. If your z/OSMF server is on a different IP address to the explorer server, for example, if you are running z/OSMF with Dynamic Virtual IP Addressing (DVIPA), you can change this by adding a ZOSMF_HOST parameter to the server.env file. For example: ZOSMF_HOST=winmvs27.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Troubleshooting installing the Zowe Application Framework

body.p: To help Zowe research any problems you might encounter, collect as much of the following information as possible and open an issue in GitHub with the collected information.

li.p: Zowe version and release level
z/OS release level
Job output and dump (if any)
Javascript console output (Web Developer toolkit accessible by pressing F12)
Log output from the Zowe Application Server
Error message codes
Screenshots (if applicable)
Other relevant information (such as the version of Node.js that is running on the Zowe Application Server and the browser and browser version).

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Troubleshooting installing Zowe CLI

body.p: The following topics contain information that can help you troubleshoot problems when you encounter unexpected behavior using Zowe CLI.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Command not found message displays when issuing npm install commands

body.p: When you issue nmp commands to install Zowe CLI, the message command not found displays in your CLI.
The command not found message displays because Node.js and NPM are not installed on your computer. To correct this behavior, install Node.js and NPM and reissue the npm command to install Zowe CLI.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: npm install -g Command Fails Due to an EPERM Error

body.p: This behavior is due to a problem with Node Package Manager (npm). There is an open issue on the npm GitHub repository to fix the defect.
If you encounter this problem, some users report that repeatedly attempting to installZowe CLIyields success. Some users also report success using the following workarounds:

li.p: Issue thenpm cache cleancommand.
Uninstall and reinstallZowe CLI. For more information, seeInstall Zowe CLI.
Add the--no-optionalflag to the end of thenpm installcommand.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Sudo syntax required to complete some installations

body.p: The installation fails on Linux or macOS.

Depending on how you configured Node.js on Linux or macOS, you might need to add the prefixsudo before thenpm install -gcommand or thenpm uninstall -gcommand. This step gives Node.jswrite access to the installation directory.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: npm install -g command fails due to npm ERR! Cannot read property 'pause' of undefined error

body.p: You receive the error messagenpm ERR! Cannot read property 'pause' of undefined when you attempt to install the product.

This behavior is due to a problem with Node Package Manager (npm). If you encounter this problem, revert to a previous version of npm that does not contain this defect. To revert to a previous version of npm, issue the following command:

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Node.js commands do not respond as expected

body.p: You attempt to issue node.js commands and you do not receive the expected output.

There might be a program that is namednodeon your path. The Node.js installer automatically adds a program that is namednodeto your path. When there are pre-existing programs that are namednodeon your computer, the program that appears first in the path is used. To correct this behavior, change the order of the programs in the path so that Node.js appears first.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Installation fails on Oracle Linux 6

body.p: You receive error messages when you attempt to install the product on an Oracle Linux 6 operating system.
Install the product on Oracle Linux 7 or another Linux or Windows OS.Zowe CLIis not compatible with Oracle Linux 6.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: How to contribute

body.p: :fireworks: :balloon: First off, thanks for taking the time to contribute! :sparkler: :confetti_ball:

We provide you a set of guidelines for contributing to Zowe documentation, which are hosted in the https://github.com/zowe/docs-site on GitHub. These are mostly guidelines, not rules. Use your best judgment, and feel free to propose content changes to this documentation.
:arrow_right: Before you get started
:arrow_right: Contributing to documentation
:arrow_right: Documentation style guide
:arrow_right: Word usage

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Before you get started

body.p: The Zowe documentation is written in Markdown markup language. Not familiar with Markdown? https://www.markdownguide.org/basic-syntax.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Contributing to documentation

body.p: You can use one of the following ways to contribute to documentation:

li.p: Send a GitHub pull request to provide a suggested edit for the content by clicking the Propose content change in GitHub link on each documentation page.
Open an issue in GitHub to request documentation to be updated, improved, or clarified by providing a comment.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Sending a GitHub pull request

body.p: You can provide suggested edit to any documentation page by using the Propose content change in GitHub link on each page. After you make the changes, you submit updates in a pull request for the Zowe content team to review and merge.
Follow these steps:

li.p: Click Propose content change in GitHub on the page that you want to update.
Make the changes to the file.
Scroll to the end of the page and enter a brief description about your change.
Optional: Enter an extended description.
Select Propose file change.
Select Create pull request.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Opening an issue for the documentation

body.p: You can request the documentation to be improved or clarified, report an error, or submit suggestions and ideas by opening an issue in GitHub for the Zowe content team to address. The content team tracks the issues and works to address your feedback.
Follow these steps:

li.p: Click the GitHub link at the top of the page.
Select Issues.
Click New issue.
Enter a title and description for the issue.
Click Submit new issue.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Documentation Style guide

body.p: This section gives writing style guidelines for the Zowe documentation. These are guidelines, not rules. Use your best judgment, and feel free to propose content changes to this documentation in a pull request.
:arrow_right: Headings and titles
:arrow_right: Technical elements
:arrow_right: Tone
:arrow_right: Word usage
:arrow_right: Graphics
:arrow_right: Abbreviations
:arrow_right: Structure and format

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Headings and titles

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Use sentence-style capitalization for headings

body.p: Capitalize only the initial letter of the first word in the text and other words that require capitalization, such as proper nouns. Examples of proper nouns include the names of specific people, places, companies, languages, protocols, and products.
Example: Verifying that your system meets the software requirements.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: For tasks and procedures, use gerunds for headings.

body.p: Example:

li.p: Building an API response
Setting the active build configuration

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: For conceptual and reference information, use noun phrases for headings.

body.p: Example:

li.p: Query language
Platform and application integration

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Use headline-style capitalization for only these items:

body.p: Titles of books, CDs, videos, and stand-alone information units.
Example:

li.p: Installation and User's Guide
Quick Start Guides or discrete sets of product documentation

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Make headings brief, descriptive, grammatically parallel, and, if possible, task oriented.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: If the subject is a functional overview, begin a heading with words such as Introduction or Overview rather than contriving a pseudo-task-oriented heading that begins with Understanding, Using, Introducing, or Learning.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Technical elements

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Variables

body.p: Style:

li.p: Italic when used outside of code examples,
Example: myHost
If wrap using angle brackets <> within code examples, italic font is not supported.
Example:
put <pax-file-name>.pax
Where pax-file-name is a variable that indicates the full name of the PAX file you download. For example, zoe-0.8.1.pax.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Message text and prompts to the user

body.p: Style: Put messages in quotation marks.
Example: "The file does not exist."

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Code and code examples

body.p: Style: Monospace
Example: java -version

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Command names, and names of macros, programs, and utilities that you can type as commands

body.p: Style: Monospace
Example: Use the BROWSE command.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Interface controls

body.p: Categories: check boxes, containers, fields, folders, icons, items inside list boxes, labels (such as Note:), links, list boxes, menu choices, menu names, multicolumn lists, property sheets, push buttons, radio buttons, spin buttons, and Tabs
Style: Bold
Example: From the Language menu, click the language that you want to use. The default selection is English.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Directory names

body.p: Style: Monospace
Example: Move the install.exe file into the newuser directory.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: File names, file extensions, and script names

body.p: Style: Monospace
Example:

li.p: Run the install.exe file.
Extract all the data from the .zip file.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Search or query terms

body.p: Style: Monospace
Example: In the Search field, enter Brightside.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Citations that are not links

body.p: Categories: Chapter titles and section titles, entries within a blog, references to industry standards, and topic titles in IBM Knowledge Center
Style: Double quotation marks
Example:

li.p: See the "Measuring the true performance of a cloud" entry in the Thoughts on Cloud blog.
See "XML Encryption Syntax and Processing" on the W3C website.
For installation information, see "Installing the product" in IBM Knowledge Center.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Tone

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Use simple present tense rather than future or past tense, as much as possible.

body.p: Example:
:heavy_check_mark: The API returns a promise.
:x: The API will return a promise.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Use simple past tense if past tense is needed.

body.p: Example:
:heavy_check_mark: The limit was exceeded.
:x: The limit has been exceeded.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Use active voice as much as possible

body.p: Example:
:heavy_check_mark: In the Limits window, specify the minimum and maximum values.
:x: The Limits window is used to specify the minimum and maximum values.
Exceptions: Passive voice is acceptable when any of these conditions are true:

li.p: The system performs the action.
It is more appropriate to focus on the receiver of the action.
You want to avoid blaming the user for an error, such as in an error message.
The information is clearer in passive voice.
Example:
:heavy_check_mark: The file was deleted.
:x: You deleted the file.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Using second person such as "you" instead of first person such as "we" and "our".

body.p: In most cases, use second person ("you") to speak directly to the reader.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: End sentences with prepositions selectively

body.p: Use a preposition at the end of a sentence to avoid an awkward or stilted construction.
Example:
:heavy_check_mark: Click the item that you want to search for.
:x: Click the item for which you want to search.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Avoid using "Please", "thank you"

body.p: In technical information, avoid terms of politeness such as "please" and "thank you". "Please" is allowed in UI only when the user is being inconvenienced.
Example: Indexing might take a few minutes. Please wait.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Avoid anthropomorphism.

body.p: Focus technical information on users and their actions, not on a product and its actions.
Example:
:heavy_check_mark: User focus: On the Replicator page, you can synchronize your local database with replica databases.
:x: Product focus: The Replicator page lets you synchronize your local database with replica databases.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Avoid complex sentences that overuse punctuation such as commas and semicolons.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Word usage

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Note headings such as Note, Important, and Tip should be formatted using the lower case and bold format.

body.p: Example:

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Use of "following"

body.p: For whatever list or steps we are introducing, the word "following" should precede a noun.
Example:

li.p: Before a procedure, use "Follow these steps:"
The <component_name> supports the following use cases:
Before you intall Zowe, review the following prerequisite installation tasks:

body.p: Avoid ending the sentence with "following".
Example:
:x: Complete the following.
:heavy_check_mark: Complete the following tasks.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Use a consistent style for referring to version numbers.

body.p: When talking about a specific version, capitalize the first letter of Version.
Example:
:heavy_check_mark: Java Version 8.1 or Java V8.1
:x: Java version 8.1, Java 8.1, or Java v8.1
When just talking about version, use "version" in lower case.
Example: Use the latest version of Java.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Avoid "may"

body.p: Use "can" to indicate ability, or use "might" to indicate possibility.
Example:

li.p: Indicating ability:
:heavy_check_mark: You can use the command line interface to update your application."
:x: "You may use the command line interface to update your application."
Indicating possibility:
:heavy_check_mark: "You might need more advanced features when you are integrating with another application. "
:x: "You may need more advanced features when you are integrating with another application."

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Use "issue" when you want to say "run/enter" a command.

body.p: Example: At a command prompt, type the following command:

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Graphics

li.p: Use graphics sparingly.
Use graphics only when text cannot adequately convey information or when the graphic enhances the meaning of the text.
When the graphic contains translatable text, ensure you include the source file for the graphic to the doc repository for future translation considerations.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Abbreviations

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Do not use an abbreviation as a noun unless the sentence makes sense when you substitute the spelled-out form of the term.

body.p: Example:
:x: The tutorials are available as PDFs.
:heavy_check_mark: The tutorials are available as PDF files.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Do not use abbreviations as verbs.

body.p: Example:
:x: You can FTP the files to the server.
:heavy_check_mark: You can use the FTP command to send the files to the server.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Do not use Latin abbreviations.

body.p: Use their English equivalents instead. Latin abbreviations are sometimes misunderstood.

row.entry: and so on. When you list a clear sequence of elements such as "1, 2, 3, and so on" and "Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and so on." Otherwise, rewrite the sentence to replace "etc." with something more descriptive such as "and other output."

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Spell out the full name and its abbreviation when the word appears for the first time. Use abbreviations in the texts that follow.

body.p: Example: Mainframe Virtual Desktop (MVD)

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Structure and format

body.p: Add "More information" to link to useful resources or related topics at the end of topics where necessary.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
topic.title: Word usage

body.p: The following table alphabetically lists the common used words and their usage guidelines.

row.entry: Capitalize "Server" when it's part of the product name
higher Do not use to describe versions of software or fix packs.
UNIX System Services z/OS UNIX System Services
